person.note: The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7, and there is no reason to think this name is particularly Jewish, see Introduction 6.5.1.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.
So in bowl 50. The additional י vowel indicates another dialect, see Introduction 2.3.5.2. The replacement of ע with א points to the decline of the laryngeals, see Introduction 2.3.1.
So in bowl 51. The additional י vowel indicates another dialect, see Introduction 2.3.5.2. The replacement of ע with ה points to the decline of the laryngeals, see Introduction 2.3.1.

The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7. However, in this case, her name may suggest she was, see Introduction 6.5.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.
In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2.
Found in a Jewish cemetery in Palestine, see Introduction 6.4.2.
This is the year in which Beth Sheʿarim was destroyed, see Introduction 8.4.2.1.
On the יתא feminine suffix see Introduction 2.3.3.6.

The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7. This one probably was, because of the biblical name Rebbeca (1) mentioned in this family, see Introduction 6.5.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.

The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7. However, in this case, her name suggests that she was, see Introduction 6.5.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.
On this form see vol. 1, Hannah (1) B/F, p. 240, n. 2.
The name and date of Pre-Christian Dura suggests a Jew, but this may simply be a Semitic name, see Introduction 6.5.1.
This is the date in which in which Dura Europos was conquered by the Sasanians and deserted, see Introduction 8.4.2.2.
On this form as a male name see under Hana (S-H/M). On androgynous names see Introduction 2.6.2.

She is mentioned on a bowl with clearly Jewish incantations and verses, but this does not necessarily imply that the clients of the magical bowls were also Jewish, see Introduction 6.7. The name may also be interpreted as Semitic, see Introduction 6.5.1.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.

The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7. This one could be Jewish, because it mentions a Rav Joseph (43), see Introduction 6.6.1, but it is accompanied by a Christian adjuration, see Introduction 6.7.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 7. On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.

person.note: Appears in rabbinic literature, has a biblical name, see Introduction 6.5 and is married to a rabbi, see Introduction 6.6.2. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Judith [2]), p. 241, but not included in the statistics.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.5.1.4, p. 52.
This is usually a male form, see vol. 1, Judah (48) B/M, pp. 114, 120, n. 112. On the interchange of male and female names see Introduction 2.6.4.
In Aramaic – אמתא.

In this tradition the discussion revolves around the Jewish status of the woman’s children. This shows that she was not Jewish to begin with. However, her name suggests that she had converted, see Introduction 6.1.2.
Was a late contemporary of Rav Huna (1), who died in 297, according to ShGa § 167, see Introduction 8.2.1.
In Hebrew – התדמורית.
Appears in rabbinic literature, has a biblical name, see Introduction 6.5, and is associated with the Temple, see Introduction 6.6.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.5.1.1, p. 52.
In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2.
The orthography of the name is biblical, but it was found in Palmyra, see Introduction 6.5.3.1. For the problem of this name in general see Introduction 6.5.3.1. CIJ did not include the inscription.
The epitaph is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.
On the additional י vowel as an alternative dialect see Introduction 2.3.5.2.

The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7. However, in the case of this woman, her name may indicate that she was Jewish, see Introduction 6.5.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.

note.ref: See above, n. 9. The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7. However, in the case of this woman, her name may indicate that she was Jewish, see Introduction 6.5.
See above, n. 10. On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.

person.note: This is probably the form מריה, see vol. 1, Mariam (26) B/F, pp. 243, 246, n. 59. On the interchange of א and ה see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.7, p. 26. On the additional י vowel as indication of another dialect see Introduction 2.3.5.2.

She is mentioned on a bowl with clearly Jewish incantations and verses, and although not all clients of the magical bowls were Jewish, see Introduction 6.7, her son-in-law’s name (ברוך אריא – Barukh Aryeh [1], S-H/M) suggests she was, see under him.

note.ref: See above, n. 10. On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.

See above, n. 9. The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7. However, in the case of this woman, her name may indicate that she was Jewish, see Introduction 6.5.
See above, n. 10. On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.

person.note: In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2.
The name may be the biblical one, but see Introduction 6.5.3.1.
The inscription is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.
See above, n. 2. In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2. This is the suggested reading of the editor, see Introduction 2.1.

In a Palestinian or European context the two biblical names mentioned in this inscription inscribed in Semitic characters would insure their Jewishness. However, Palmyra in this context is unique, see Introduction 6.5.3.1.
The epitaph is not dated. Late antique date assumed, see Introduction 8.4.3.
On the interchange of ה and א see vol. 1, Introduction 2.4.2.7, p. 26.

Although the authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, it is not at all clear that their customer were, see Introduction 6.7. However, because of her name, this woman probably was, see Introduction 6.5.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.
Appears in rabbinic literature, has a biblical name, see Introduction 6.5, and is the mother of a rabbi, see Introduction 6.6.2.
Her son was a contemporary of Rava (Abba [17]), who died in 352 CE, according to ShGa § 176, see Introduction 8.2.1.
In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2. Usually this is a male form of the name, see under Shabtai B/M. On the interchange of male and female names see Introduction 2.6.3.
Perhaps she is Jewish because of her name, but see Introduction 6.5.31. CIJ did not include the inscription.
The epitaph is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2. Usually this is a male form of the name, see under Shabtai B/M. On the interchange of male and female names see Introduction 2.6.3.
See above, n. 3. Perhaps she is Jewish because of her name, but see Introduction 6.5.31. CIJ did not include the inscription.

person.note: The epitaph is not dated. Late antique date assumed, see Introduction 8.4.3.
On this form see vol. 1, Salome (9) B/F, pp. 249, 251-2, n. 26.
The name is deciphered in CIJ 1226, but a photograph of the inscription is mistakenly reproduced in CIJ 1215.
The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.4.1. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Salome [9] B/F), p. 249, but not included in the statistics.

All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. Dura-Europos (1959) 100, 101.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.
On this form see vol. 1, Salome (10) B/F, pp. 249, 252, n. 30.
The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.4.1. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Salome [10], B/F), p. 249, but not included in the statistics.

note.ref: See above, n. 5. All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. Dura-Europos (1959) 100, 101.
See above, n. 6. See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.

person.note: On this form see vol. 1, Salome (11) B/F, pp. 249, 251-2, n. 26.
The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.4.1. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Salome [11], B/F), p. 249, but not included in the statistics.

note.ref: See above, n. 5. All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. Dura-Europos (1959) 100, 101.
See above, n. 6. See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.

person.note: In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2.
Jewishness suggested based on name, see Introduction 6.5. The name (or word) שלום appears elswhere in Palmyrene inscriptions, but only here is it a female name, see Introduction 2.6.3.1.
The inscription is dated, see Introduction 8.4.1.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2. And see also Introduction 6.4.3.

Date suggested by the editor, see Introduction 8.4.2.3. For doubts about it see D. Shapira, “Gleanings on Jews of Greater Iran under the Sasanians according to the Oldest Armenian and Georgian Texts,” Iran and the Caucasus 12 (2008-9) 7-10.

On the interchange of ש and ס in Eastern dialects see Introduction 2.3.4.1. On the additional י vowel as an indication of dialect see Introduction 2.3.5.2. The interchange of ו and י is a scribal or reading error, see Introduction 2.7.1.
Perhaps this is the title “mother,” see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.2, p. 33.

The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7. However, the parallel between this name and אמא שלום of rabbinic literature (see vol. 1, Salome [7] B/F) suggests that this client was Jewish, see Introduction 6.5.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.
For this form see vol. 1, Salome (19) B/F, pp. 249, 252, n. 48.

The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7. However, in this case, the name suggests that this client was Jewish, see Introduction 6.5.

note.ref: See above, n. 23. On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.

person.note: This is the Arabic transliteration of the biblical name, see Introduction 2.3.5.3.1. Ṭabarī also records this form as for the name of Abraham’s wife (Annales, I; 226).
Nöldeke, Beiträge, 53, cites verses of her poetry from a certain manuscript of the Kitāb al-Aghānī (Sprengersche). I did not see this manuscript.
Of the Banū Qurayẓa, see Introduction 6.1.1.1.1.
Nöldekes book is dedicated to pre-Islamic poetry, see Nöldeke, Beiträge, I-II.
In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2. On this form see vol. 1, Sarah (2) B/F, pp. 254-5, n. 5, and also vol. 3, Sarah (1) B/F, p. 193.
The inscription was found in a Jewish tomb in Jerusalem, see Introduction 6.4.1. This person is recorded in vol. 1 (Sarah [2], B/F), p. 254, but not included in the statistics.

All the inscriptions in this tomb were identified as Palmyrene, because some of them were written in the Palmyrene script and many had Latin names, which were not typical at the time in Jerusalem, but seem to have been more so in Palmyra, see e.g. the list of Palmyrene soldiers in Welles et al. Dura-Europos (1959) 100, 101.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.6.1, p. 52.
For this form see vol. 1, Sarah (6) B/F, p. 255, n. 17, and vol 3, Sarah (2) B/F.
In Greek – Μισηνή, see Oppenheimer, Babylonia Judaica, 241-56.
Found in a Jewish cemetery in Palestine, see Introduction 6.4.2.
This is the year in which Beth Sheʿarim was destroyed, see Introduction 8.4.2.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 6. In Palmyrene script, see Introduction 2.8.2. On this form see vol. 1, Sarah (2) B/F, pp. 254-5, n. 5, and also vol. 3, Sarah (1) B/F, p. 193.

person.note: The authors of the Aramaic incantation bowls were Jewish, but there is no reason to suppose that all their clients were, see Introduction 6.7.
On the dating of the Aramaic incantation bowls see Introduction 8.5.
The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2, and this is a biblical name, see Introduction 6.5.
The amulet is not dated. Late antique date assumed, see Introduction 8.4.3.

div.note: Biblical, Exod 6:23. אלישבע was Aaron’s wife.
Biblical, e.g. Esth 2:7. אסתר was the queen who gave her name to a biblical book.

ברכה means “blessing” in Hebrew, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 195. The name ברכה is recorded for a male in the Bible, see 1 Chr 12:3. On the interchange between male and female names see vol. 1, Introduction 1.5.2, p. 15.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 3:20. חוה was the name of the first woman.
Biblical, e.g. 1 Sam 1:2. חנה was the prophet Samuel’s mother.
Biblical, Gen 26:34. The name is derived from the male יהודה. יהודית was Esau’s wife. The most famous Judith of Second Temple times is ̓Ιουδείθ of the apocryphal book by that name.
Biblical, e.g. Exod 15:20. מרים was Moses’ sister.
Biblical, e.g. Ruth 1:2. נעמי was Ruth’s mother-in-law.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 22:23. רבקה was Isaac’s wife.
Biblical, e.g. Gen 29:6. רחל was Jacob’s wife.

שבתית is the feminine form of the biblical שבתאי (e.g. Ezra 10:15). It is, however, never mentioned in the Bible. It was probably invented in post-biblical times, see vol. 3, Introduction 1.1.2.1, p. 6. In vol. 1, I mistakenly listed it under Greek female names (p. 323). The name and its many derivatives became very popular in the Western Diaspora, because of its association with the Jewish Shabbat, but not in the Eastern one, see Introduction 1.1.1.3.
In the Bible שלום is recorded only as a man’s name (one of the last kings of Israel, e.g. 2 Kgs 15:10), but see vol. 1, Table 8, p. 57.
Biblical, e.g. Gen. 17:15. שרה was Abraham’s wife.
